NewsDetail.Author: Orren Squires
NewsDetail.BodyCopy:
It is unfortunate that we have to ask that question because the I-Learn Grade Center really is packed with great features.  But as 53% of you told us in the recent survey, it is very frustrating to use those features.

While I only teach about 100 students and don’t approach the number of students a typical faculty member has each semester, I can honestly say that I’m one of those 53%.  So what is Grade Center really good for?  Here are 3 things to simplify Grade Center and make it work for you:

  1. Grade reporting instead of grade calculating: Research shows that the feature students like best in I-Learn is the ability to log in at any time and see their current standing.  However, many teachers are nervous about how Grade Center is actually calculating their grades.  If you are one of those, use an Excel spreadsheet to do the calculations and simply use the I-Learn Grade Center to report grades to students.  It requires that extra step but you’ll likely sleep better at night.
  2. Simplify your grading structure: On a weekly basis I get teachers who call asking how to get Grade Center to match their grading structures.   I think my favorite so far is, “How do I triple weight my grades?”  While possible, it is quite complex and there are so many places to make a mistake that I convinced the teacher it would be better to simplify how he graded this particular set of assignments.  Students really do appreciate a simple grading structure that is easy to calculate.  If you find it a struggle to get Grade Center to calculate grades the way you want, chances are your students are having a hard time understanding the explanation in your syllabus.  Ask your students to explain your grading structure to you and you may get a surprise!
  3. Use it to organize assignment submissions:  One really nice feature of Grade Center is the fact that when a student submits an assignment, it is organized and available for grading.  No more papers to file in a folder in the desk.  Using Grade Center to organize assignments and keep your desk clutter free can be a wonderful thing. 
  4. Use Grade Center to do automatic grading:  We all like to find things that save us time and this can be a big one.  If you are giving simple tests and quizzes that require multiple choice, true/false, or other simple questions, you can use grade center to automatically grade those tests and quizzes.  Keep in mind though that essay, short answer, and other types of questions that require the student to type an answer will require a teacher to grade.
  5. Student management: Another nice feature of Grade Center is the fact that it automatically enrolls and removes students who add and drop classes without any teacher intervention. 

If you decide you want to be adventurous and use more of the features of Grade Center be on the lookout for the article “Grade Center Gotchas:  tips to avoid catastrophes,” the next in the Simplifying I-Learn series.
